I am heading to Fort Carson in September! 
If you are transitioning out of the military and interested in learning more about franchise opportunities with Signal 88 Security, come meet with me! I will be available all day on the 13th for 1 on 1 meetings; send me an email at packermann@signal88.com and I will schedule a convenient time for us to meet. 
Event Title: Fort Carson Transition Summit
Event Date: Tuesday, September 13, - Wednesday, September 14, 2016 
Event Location: Ft. Carson, Colorado, USA
Join us for a free hiring fair and transition summit for service members, veterans, and military spouses. This summit features participation by and speakers from Fort Carson, the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, the U.S. Department of Labor Veterans’ Employment and Training Services, Soldier for Life, the U.S. Department of Defense’s Transition to Veterans Program Office, the U.S. Small Business Administration, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation’s Hiring Our Heroes, and local chambers of commerce.
This transition summit will feature interactive and informative panel discussions, recruiter training, and a networking reception focused on improving competitive employment for service members, veterans, and military spouses. A hiring fair and career forum will be held on the 14th.
REGISTER HERE: Fort Carson Transition Summit Registration    http://www.cvent.com/d/qvq8xw/4W (cut and paste into your browser)
This transition summit is being held in partnership with the George W. Bush Institute and the USO and is sponsored by CarMax, Lockheed Martin, MAXIMUS, Toyota, and USAA.

As my dad (retired military) always said he was neither a lender nor a borrower. 
    But after our experience my husband and I no longer hold parties or really even let anyone on our property unless they are licensed and insured.  
     A few years ago I suffered a concussion and Tricare sent us a letter as to who owned the property where I fell so they could file against their insurance for reimbursement.  We sent the letter back explaining we owned the RV I fell in as the floor was wet and I slipped.  They then responded whose property was the RV sitting  on at the time of the fall and who owned the vehicle it was attached to.  We responded our property which they responded is the property rented or owned.  So my final response was to inform them it was all owned by us it was my own fault and nobody was to blame but me it was an accident and I included a copy of the Truck insurance card, RV insurance card and the home owners policy.  
       Anymore even if the person doesn't go after you the insurance company will.  FYI if anyone goes to Parkview and their injury happened on your property or in your car the hospital automatically files a lien against you until the persons hospital bills are paid in full!!

OK folks, what they are working on here is strictly about form, specifically landing on the balls of the feet instead of the heels.  It drastically reduces impact absorbed throughout the body and is especially good for those of us with lower back and knee pain.  It takes some getting used to and must be implemented gradually.  They also teach this in Master Fitness Course and has reduced a lot of pain I had with running, especially with spinal arthritis and two bulging discs.  I would HIGHLY recommend looking into POSE RUNNING TECHNIQUE.  Hope this helps clear some misconceptions.

Thank god. During the old process I made a mistake (looked at the wrong LES were the $$ amounts were different) while my husband was deployed and had to apply for an AER loan (the only time we've ever done so in 6 years) and his chain of command ripped into me. I made a mistake. I acknowledged I made a mistake. They happen in life. But this 1SGT literally spent 20 minutes lecturing me on my budget and how I spend too much money on food and how i should be able to feed myself and my kids on $120- for two weeks easily. I was in tears by the end of that meeting. The AER people on the other hand were polite, professional and helped us. Seems much more reasonable to leave the professionals to do their jobs rather than some soldier who has a thousand different responsibilities and no *extensive* training in helping to provide and evaluate for emergency financial services.
Kevin Coderre Sr. - FYI

I don't know about cheaper. $35 just for a visit ($34 at the closest off post vet), $300-$400 to spay my dog while it's $194 at the closest off post vet (Even cheaper at hamlett). I remember when office visits were $4 on post. But now, seems like regular vet pricing. I'm glad that military installations have vets and offer services but don't say they're cheaper when they aren't.

Colorado Springs is a very competitive market due to the large number of veterinary clinics in the city.  Army Vet Services are cheaper on a large number of services, but not all.  Because prices are identical across the DOD, your biggest savings are going to be at the vet clinics on smaller installations where veterinary clinics are far more sparse.  Hard to compare to Hamlett when they are able to receive subsidies and accept donations to cover costs.  The nice thing about outside vets are that they can provide a la carte services.  Hamlett's price per vaccine is actually higher, but they aren't required to give your pet an exam, which will keep costs low as well. Vet Services offers a wide array of things that are MUCH cheaper than outside clinics such as x-rays, ultrasounds, and bloodwork.  Like with anything else, shop around and get more bang for your buck, whether it's off installation or not.  Cheers!

We had a conversation a while ago about the difficulty of the new EIB vs. the old one. Just figured this was relevant.

Except for the pre-reqs. there is no comparison.  You can get 2 no-go's per lane and still pass on the new EIB. The old one you could get 2 no-gos total in over 30 different stations and if you double no-goed one station you were out completely.

Yeah, and you also got to go to the practice tent at each station, see the entire performance measures list, and practice as long as you want until you're ready to test. And like you said, the pre-reqs that you could do over and over again until you passed with the old standard, as opposed to the new one with a one-time go/no-go standard. Your right, there is no comparison.

Did you get your EIB prior to 2010, and did you ever grade for the new EIB? If you didn't then your opinion is extremely biased.   You guys ALL got to practice for 3 straight weeks on the lanes, so don't me give this "oh you got to practice"non-sense. I sat there for 3 weeks watching everyone go through the new and improved EIB and practice endlessly for 10 hours a day.  Then on test week I watched NCO's and LT's fail miserably at a 9 line and forget to pull the pin on their practice grenade and STILL pass my lane....you're right, there is no comparison.  Stop crying and move on, instead of setting out on some quest to try and prove how tough your EIB was.

Joe McKnight you are absolutely right. But, during Women's History Month we highlight the accomplishments of women who have overcome obstacles and opened doors so that others can also find success.

I celebrate women's accomplishments as I had no women leaders as role models. Many of the males were so anti female when I first came in, I felt like I was alone. I remember hearing a company commander at Ft Stewart, upon hearing of an incoming soldier, "Not another damned female." That was nothing compared to other disparaging remarks & behavior like not getting a patch because Just Cause wasn't a real war, to ignoring complaints of assaults, to even our leadership physically attacking us. I used to tell the young females "If you can wake up in the morning, beat up 2 men & go to work like nothing happened, then you can be in the Army." Combat duty was daily for us - with no patch ever awarded! To this female general: Great Job! To the Army for celebrating women instead of disparaging women: Great Job!

I've needed an AER loan once in my 5 year career.  I needed to get my pregnant wife and 3 kids out of a third floor, 2 bedroom, apartment before I deployed since my pregnant wife would not be able to do it without me.  Landlord refused to let me out in time since my orders didn't come until about a month before we left and the SCRA allows them 30 days after the following billing cycle (basically up to 60 days)... I was forced to get a new place, and have two rent payments for one month.  Even though it was not yet due, AER classified it as "past due debt" and refused to help.  I'm glad I donated my entire career before that just to be denied in my time of need.

Delayed Reporting.

Fort Carson is REPORTING STATUS RED until 0930 on 21 January 2015. The Senior Commander has ordered a phased arrival of all non essential personnel until 0930. Those personnel who live on Fort Carson or within 5 miles of the installation will report NLT than 1 hour after their normal report time. Those personnel who live 5-15 miles from Fort Carson will report NLT that 1 hour and 30 minutes after their normal report time and those personnel who live more than 15 miles from Fort Carson will report NLT than 2 hours after their normal report time. Stay at the normal report time of 0630 and stay with the "phased arrival and release," when there is bad weather, because that was actually smart. Stop focusing so much on pt and just focus on soldiers safety and the safety of the civilian community.

My MOM Loved Fort Carson, CHARLINE GEREPKA .
Charline Gerepka HAMILTON Charline Gerepka, LTC, U.S. Army (Retired), 58, of Hamilton passed away Friday, Dec. 12, 2014, at the University Medical Center of Princeton at Plainsboro. Born and raised in Trenton, Charline joined the U. S. Army Reserves as an Army Nurse Corps (ANC) officer in 1988. She was activated to Fort Bragg, where she treated many injured servicemen serving in the Panama Conflict. Charline went on to active duty service in 1992. She deployed to Haiti in 1996, where she served six months caring for more than 600 United Nations troops. Afterwards, for her exceptional efforts, she was selected to receive the Nurse Excellence Award, given by the U.S. Army to one outstanding nurse among hundreds of candidates. Charline's last posting was director of medical readiness at Fort Carson, CO, until her retirement in 2013. Charline took great pride in assisting with Christmas activities and served as hostess for numerous Christmas holidays. Charline worked 22 consecutive Christmas holidays so others could spend the day with their families. She was a member of Sigma Theta Tau, the National Honor Society of Nursing. Daughter of the late Norwood and Essie Hammonds Locklear, and sister of the late Patricia Simms and Jeanine Coltre, Charline is survived by her husband of 23 years, Peter Gerepka; daughter, Sherice Soganic and husband, Kenneth Kassner, of Ewing; daughter, Jamie Soganic of Ewing; grandchildren, Katelyn Croke and Kyle Kassner; brothers and sisters-in-law, Richard and Irene Locklear of North Carolina, and Jimmy and Carrie Locklear of Hamilton; sisters and brothers-in-law, Lynda Locklear of Hamilton, Synda and Dave LaMont of Hamilton, Diane and Fred Wyckoff of Maryland; and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Calling hours will be on Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 12 noon at Kingston & Kemp Funeral Home, 260 White Horse Ave., Hamilton, KingstonandKemp.com. Entombment with military honors will follow at Greenwood Cemetery Mausoleum, 1800 Hamilton Ave., Hamilton. Memorial contributions may be made in Charline's honor to Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, KS 66675, or online at woundedwarriorproject.org. Kingston & Kemp Funeral Home, Inc. 260 White Horse Ave. Hamilton, NJ 08610 (609) 585-7321

There was nothing more inspirational than being out before the sun dawns... hearing cadence being called... and the sun coming up... and seeing the Regimental Commander... saluting and calling out "Brave Rifles, SIR!" And the 70th Colonel saluting back.  One knew he had your back.  When it mattered most. What you do in the dark, counts in the light.

... In reference to?  What kind of emergency is this in regards to...?

A little sensitive right now considering the current situation abroad.  The schools typically call and send texts/emails during an emergency crisis to keep parents updated.  Are there any indications of "unique" emergency circumstances that parents should be more keen to?  This is a little alarming.
I don't find this alarming at all.  I find it to be very helpful and am thankful that information like this is given as a reminder to be aware and on alert just in case.
This is only an informational post during National Preparedness Month.

Well as any normal parent would, i did find it somewhat alarming.  As a parent you shouldn't need a reminder.  However if this is just to say stay on your p's and q's when it pertains to your child's school emergency procedures then thanks?  I feel a message like this would be better directed to the actual school-to send home information in regards to emergency procedures in the event something were to happen.  The whole food, water and shelter in place statements warranted questioning the underlying intent of the message.  Those statements indicated an emergency procedure outside the scope of the normal weather emergency or potential threat from from an individual.  It's not an informational post but rather a post suggesting inquiring into the schools emergency preparedness.  And don't confuse what I'm saying.  I do appreciate information, this however did throw up a red flag for me.

I have two angels but I don't know their names. ( True Story! Please pass this around, who knows I might find them yet! )

Two military men that no one seems to know.
I thank GOD they were there at my lowest low!
One white one black, I'm so glad they had my back!
Stationed at Fort Carson, Colorado.
My angels wouldn't let me go!
A belt they each removed from their hips,
To wrap around my left arm and return the color to my lips.
I long to say thank you and for them I pray,
Because of them my son has a mom today!
A van hit my bike and flipped me around,
I should've died on that cold blood soaked ground.
I have two angels I don't know their  name,
But since August 28, 2012 I just haven't been the same.
If you should know how to find them,
Or where they might be, 
Give them a hug and say thank you for me!
Hold their hands and with them pray, 
Tell them I love them, 
And think of them each and every day!

UPDATE: There is ample parking at various locations on Fort Carson with Wetzel Avenue parking lot being primary. From there, military police will direct traffic to the next nearest parking location. All are within walking distance to the park. Handicap parking is available at the parking lot on Sheridan Avenue, which will be blocked off. MPs will allow eligible drivers through.
UPDATE: While most activities at the event are free, there are charges for all of the inflatables (Climbing wall, bungee jump, bounce houses).

UPDATE: In the event of rain, there will be tents at the park that people can use to take cover from the rain. In the event of lightning, people will be asked to return to their cars until the area is declared safe, and then the event will continue.

I was at Carson from 96-97, and again from 98-01. I seen the changes from the post over the years. When I first came to Carson it was mandatory that everyone stopped on post, to include civilians and you were to exit your vehicle no matter who you were. The MPs always hit the intersections all over post to stop traffic and make sure that you were out of your vehicle saluting the flag, or standing outside your vehicle as a civilian showing the respect our nations colors deserve. Once I returned from overseas I noticed a decline in the ethical decisions of everyone on the post. Some gave the respect and some didn't, but no one stopped traffic nor did anyone seem to care when people kept driving. I was brought up through the ranks that no matter what you were doing at that point of the colors being retired for the day or displayed for the day, if you heard the music or cannons, you stopped and paid respect. 
Once I got out I then got a job as a civilian contractor and worked there for 7 yrs and over that time no one stopped for anything, unless there was a convoy rolling through. The military has gone south of what they should be, to many and to much disrespectful crap going on throughout all branches. The military needs to go back to what it was, but it may be to far gone at this point!!

HOW COLD IS IT? COLD ENOUGH FOR FROSTBITE!  Frostbite may affect any part of the body. The hands, feet, nose, and ears are the most vulnerable.  It occurs when the skin and body tissues are exposed to cold temperature for a prolonged period of time.  IT’S DANGEROUS.  Wear suitable clothing in cold temperatures and protect exposed areas. I remember winters at Fort Carson 66-69. The old wooden drafty WWII barracks with coal furnaces got very cold some nights. Sometimes the butt cans froze. Not much snow. After a rare heavy snow we had to get brooms and go to the motor pool to remove snow from vehicles. As we were standing around waiting the command came “RIGHT SHOULDER BROOM” At that point most of us lost it. It was so cold but so hard to stop laughing. I haven’t thought of that in years. : )

I'm inquiring about how chapter cases are being handled with the transition center being closed.  We have two Soldiers, one with a final out date of 7 OCT and the other at 8 OCT. I'm very familiar with the process and that doesn't seem right and since transition center is closed I am not able to ask for their guidance on this situation. I am aware that on their final out date, they digitally sign their DD214 and after that they go to DEERS and surrender their CAC cards along with any dependents id card if any.  I'm also aware that if they're unable to clear all the agencies by their final out date that it will become the unit's responsibility to clear them completely and provide transition center with the completed clearing papers. I just want to clarify whether or not our rear detachment chain of command's guidance is legitimate or not and if not what are our options with our chapter cases. Thank you very much.

Effective 7:30 a.m. Oct. 7, those services in support of Soldiers transitioning (ETSing, retiring, or chaptering) from the U.S. Army will be operational with limited staff. In addition, the Fort Carson ID card center will be operational with reduced services. Additionally, all permanent change of station moves with an order date before Oct. 1 Will continue. The order date reflects when the order was issued and must not be confused with the report date. Moves with an order date on or after Oct. 1 will be limited as follows: 1) moves to an excepted (in direct support of national security) activity will continue; 2) moves from an excepted activity will continue only to the extent the commander of the excepted activity determines it essential to the mission or required to enhance support of excepted activities; 3) accession and training moves associated with recruitment and initial entry training will continue. We appreciate your patience. As more information becomes available we will post it here. For specific questions on whether a PCS move applies, please visit the transition center.

As a sexual assault survivor I'm still confused as to how this is an Army problem... The Army doesn't create these sexual predators.... This happens LONG before they are even old enough to join... Place the blame where it belongs.... If you are a sexual predator..... SEEK HELP and stop the cycle.. If you are a parent of a child who is sexually assaulted.... GET THEM HELP before they become predators themselves, if you are a parent of a child that sexually assaults another.... GET THEM HELP, don't sweep it under the rug and think they will 'grow out of it'. If you are a victim call LOCAL AUTHORITIES.... NOT THE MPs..... If the local police are called, the Military is notified and kept informed but they are NOT in control of the investigation, prosecution, or punishment of the offender.... This goes for Military personnel AND civilians BOTH... Just because you either live on post, work on post, the offender is Military, your spouse is Military, doesn't mean that the MPs are the end all be all of your personal safety. IMHO, the ONLY time the local authorities shouldn't be the first call is if you are a Soldier and are deployed (and this is where the Military should be stepping up). As for sexual harassment... This again starts LONG before the Military.... teach your children what is appropriate and what is not. The cycle will end the moment no child ever hears a dirty or offensive joke and are taught that it is alright behavior. And until then... make sure there is a CLEAR line amongst your co-workers and battle buddies.. if there is no grey area, then there is no confusion...... "You speak to me, about me, or around me in that way, and I will make sure you are reported"... And if reporting it doesn't solve the issue, then there is always someone higher to go to... You would be AMAZED how much weight a letter to your Congress man/woman holds... What it boils down to is personal responsibility.... keep informed, keep alert, keep safe. If the worst happens, take control back... don't hand it over to the MPs and the Military.

You are correct about your statement of WHERE and HOW a predator is born Melinda. I would like to ask you IF you received justice for your assault, and WHO achieved it for you. I did not stop with MPs, Provost Marshall, Post Command, and even the DOD. I involved civilian authorities, including letters to the Congressman, supporting evidence, including hospital findings, and made sure everything could be validated and used registered mail, yet for some reason, the broom STILL won. The only recourse I could see would have been an actual court proceeding that I could not afford. Given my experience, sometimes JUSTICE is just unobtainable.

Love & Prayers to all those affected by these fires.  We are retired Airforce in Mesa Verde right now watching the Weber Fire's containment and we had a lightening struck today. I am all to familiar with fire re-birth.  My house burned down last year, my children and grandchildren  survived 2 house fires within 4 years. They moved into my house after the first fire only to have to start over again after my house fire.  Starting over isn't easy and is traumatic but as long as we survive it with our families we can be grateful!  My heart goes out to you all  ~ Time will heal.
